column1: Long Branch was a beach resort town in the late 18th century
column2: named for its location along a branch of the South Shrewsbury River. In the 19th century
column3: theatrical performers of the day often gathered and performed there. It was visited by presidents Chester A. Arthur
column5: Ulysses S. Grant
column9: and Woodrow Wilson. Seven Presidents Park
column11: is named in honor of their visits. The Church of the Presidents
column13: is the only structure left in Long Branch associated with them.

column1: President Grant and his family summered at their beachfront cottage in Long Branch the first year of his presidency in 1869 and for most of the rest of Grant's life. During this time
column2: Long Branch came to be called the "summer capital". President James A. Garfield was brought to Long Branch in the hope that the fresh air and quiet might aid his recovery after being shot on July 2
column4: an incident that left the assassin's bullet lodged in his spine. He died here on September 19
column6: exactly two months before his 50th birthday. The Garfield Tea House
column7: constructed from railroad ties that had been laid to carry Garfield's train
column8: is in Elberon.The famous Long Branch Saloon of the American Old West
column11: was given its name by its first owner
column13: who had moved west from Long Branch
column15: his hometown.Originally a resort town with a few hotels and large estates and many farms in the early 20th century
column16: Long Branch grew in population. Italian
column17: Irish and Jewish immigrants settled in during this period. During the 1930s
column18: the city used government policies to enforce racial segregation against Blacks at local beaches
column19: assigning all black applicants for beach passes to a single
column21: Long Branch like many other towns had developed new residential spots and housing to make room for the growing population. Many of the former farms of Long Branch were transformed into residential suburbs. Many of the estates and a few old historic resorts (with the addition of many new ones) still remain.

column2: Long Branch lost much of its activity as a theater spot. In addition
column3: the opening of the Garden State Parkway in the mid-1950s allowed shore visitors to access points further south
column4: which added to Long Branch's decline. The civil unrest of the 1960s caused riots in neighboring Asbury Park
column5: and many fled the shore cities for the suburban towns west of the beach. Decades later
column7: more dilapidated parts of the resort town were condemned and redeveloped
column8: in part by using eminent domain legislation.

column1: Long Branch still continues to be a popular resort area. Many people from New York City travel or settle into the area to escape the crowded city and enjoy Long Branch's beaches. The area also attracts some tourists from the Philadelphia area as well.

column3: Long Branch was one of many shore communities that were devastated by Hurricane Sandy. Although Sandy's winds were powerful
column4: Long Branch's position between Long Beach Island and Sea Bright gave Long Branch a much larger wall of security because it could not be engulfed by surrounding waters. Despite this mainland advantage
column5: there were still several instances of flooding in Long Branch during the storm. Many residents went without electricity for as long as two weeks. The boardwalk was destroyed; the city began rebuilding it in 2015
column7: making it the last boardwalk damaged by Sandy to be rebuilt.

column1: Long Branch takes its name from the "long branch" or south branch of the Shrewsbury River.According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city had a total area of 6.29 square miles (16.28 km2)
column3: including 5.12 square miles (13.27 km2) of land and 1.16 square miles (3.01 km2) of water (18.49%).The city borders the Monmouth County communities of Deal
column5: Ocean Township

column2: Long Branch was a major destination for beachgoers
column3: along with Asbury Park
column4: and enjoyed an upscale connotation with tourists. Long Branch is home to Seven Presidents Oceanfront Park
column5: named for the United States presidents who visited the fashionable resort town
column11: Woodrow Wilson and James Garfield.Long Branch's fame as the Nation's First Seaside Resort waned in the years following World War II. The defining moment marking the end of this era occurred on June 8
column12: 1987 when the largest fire in the history of the city destroyed the landmark amusement pier and adjoining Haunted Mansion
column13: "Kid's World" Amusement Park and other businesses.

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Long Branch has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa). Cfa climates are characterized by all months having an average temperature > 32.0 °F (0.0 °C)
column3: at least four months with an average temperature ≥ 50.0 °F (10.0 °C)
column4: at least one month with an average temperature ≥ 71.6 °F (22.0 °C) and no significant precipitation difference between seasons. Although most summer days are slightly humid with a cooling afternoon sea breeze in Long Branch
column5: episodes of heat and high humidity can occur with heat index values > 104 °F (40 °C). Since 1981
column6: the highest air temperature was 100.6 °F (38.1 °C) on August 9
column8: and the highest daily average mean dew point was 77.7 °F (25.4 °C) on August 13
column10: 2019. July is the peak in thunderstorm activity and the average wettest month is August. Since 1981
column11: the wettest calendar day was 5.82 inches (148 mm) on August 27
column13: the average annual extreme minimum air temperature is 3.9 °F (−15.6 °C). Since 1981
column14: the coldest air temperature was −5.9 °F (−21.1 °C) on January 22
column15: 1984. Episodes of extreme cold and wind can occur with wind chill values < −6 °F (−21 °C). The average seasonal (November-April) snowfall total is 18 to 24 inches (46 to 61 cm) and the average snowiest month is February which corresponds with the annual peak in nor'easter activity.

column1: According to the A. W. Kuchler U.S. potential natural vegetation types
column2: Long Branch would have a dominant vegetation type of Appalachian Oak (104) with a dominant vegetation form of Eastern Hardwood Forest (25). The plant hardiness zone is 7a with an average annual extreme minimum air temperature of 3.9 °F (−15.6 °C). The average date of first spring leaf-out is March 23 and fall color typically peaks in early-November.

column1: Portions of the city are part of a joint Urban Enterprise Zone (UEZ) with Asbury Park
column2: one of 32 zones covering 37 municipalities statewide. The city was selected in 1994 as one of a group of 10 zones added to participate in the program. In addition to other benefits to encourage employment and investment within the UEZ
column3: shoppers can take advantage of a reduced 3.3125% sales tax rate (half of the ​6 5⁄8% rate charged statewide) at eligible merchants. Established in November 1994
column4: the city's Urban Enterprise Zone status expires in November 2025.

column1: The City of Long Branch is governed under the Mayor-Council (Plan A) form of municipal government under the Faulkner Act
column2: enacted by direct petition as of July 1
column3: 1966. The city is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the five-member City Council
column4: whose members are elected at-large on a non-partisan basis in the May municipal elections to serve concurrent four-year terms of office.As of 2020
column5: the Mayor of Long Branch is John Pallone. Members of the City Council are Dr. Mary Jane Celli
column8: Dr. Anita Voogt and Rose Widdis. The mayor and city council members serve concurrent terms of office ending on June 30

column1: Long Branch's public schools are operated by the Long Branch Public Schools
column2: serving children in pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade. The district is one of 31 former Abbott districts statewide
column3: which are now referred to as "SDA Districts" based on the requirement for the state to cover all costs for school building and renovation projects in these districts under the supervision of the New Jersey Schools Development Authority. All Long Branch Public Schools are free
column4: including the district's preschool programs which are full-day and accommodate children ages 3–5 years old. Long Branch schools offer free breakfast each morning for the students. In addition
column5: Long Branch Public Schools provide free summer programs for most of the summer.

column1: Long Branch is connected to New York City and Northern New Jersey via NJ Transit trains running on the North Jersey Coast Line. The Long Branch station
column2: located three blocks away from the beach
column3: marks the end of electrified trackage
column4: where passengers continuing south must change to diesel-powered trains. A second station is located at Elberon district just north of the borough of Deal. In the past there were stops in the West End neighborhood and on Broadway
column5: but they were closed to reduce travel time to New York City.

column1: Local bus transportation is provided by NJ Transit on the 831 and 837 routes. Transportation to New York City is provided by Academy Bus' Route 36 and Shore Points routes.
